9361 old ¦ As a prefix to verbs and their derivatives, expresses beyond, over, and, if not standing by itself, leaves the accent on the verb or its derivative; as, <s>ati-kram</s> (√ <s>kram</s>), to overstep, <ab>Ved.</ab> <ab>Inf.</ab> <s>ati-kra/me</s>, (fit) to be walked on, to be passed, <ls>RV. i, 105, 16</ls>, <s>ati-kra/maRa</s> <lex type="nhw">n.</lex> See <ab>s.v.</ab> When prefixed to nouns, not derived from verbs, it expresses beyond, surpassing, as, <s>ati-kaSa</s>, past the whip, <s>ati-mAnuza</s>, superhuman, &c. ;

; <L>28800.1<pc>165,2<k1>id<k2>i/d<e>1A
102623 old ¦ indeed, assuredly (especially, in strengthening an antithesis, <ab>e.g.</ab> <s>ya/TA va/Santi devA/s ta/Te/<srs/>d asat</s>, as the gods wish it, thus indeed it will be, <ls>RV. viii, 28, 4</ls>; <s>di/psanta i/d ripa/vo nA/<srs/>ha deBuH</s>, the enemies wishing indeed to hurt were in nowise able to hurt, <ls>RV. i, 147, 3</ls>). <s>id</s> is often added to words expressing excess or exclusion (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>viSva it</s>, every one indeed; <s>SaSvad it</s>, constantly indeed; <s>eka it</s>, one only). At the beginning of sentences it often adds emphasis to pronouns, prepositions, particles (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>tvam it</s>, thou indeed; <s>yadi it</s>, if indeed, &c.) <s>id</s> occurs often in the <s1 slp1="fg">Ṛg</s1>-<s1 slp1="veda">veda</s1> and <s1 slp1="aTarva">Atharva</s1>-<s1 slp1="veda">veda</s1>, seldom in the <s1 slp1="brAhmaRa">Brāhmaṇa</s1>s, and its place is taken in classical <ns>Sanskṛt</ns> by <s>eva</s> and other particles.<info lex="inh"/>
;
102623 new ¦ indeed, assuredly (especially, in strengthening an antithesis, <ab>e.g.</ab> <s>ya/TA va/Santi devA/s ta/Te/<srs/>d asat</s>, as the gods wish it, thus indeed it will be, <ls>RV. viii, 28, 4</ls>; <s>di/psanta i/d ripa/vo nA/<srs/>ha deBuH</s>, the enemies wishing indeed to hurt were in nowise able to hurt, <ls>RV. i, 147, 3</ls>). <s>id</s> is often added to words expressing excess or exclusion (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>viSva it</s>, every one indeed; <s>SaSvad it</s>, constantly indeed; <s>eka it</s>, one only). At the beginning of sentences it often adds emphasis to pronouns, prepositions, particles (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>tvam it</s>, thou indeed; <s>yadi it</s>, if indeed, &c.) <s>id</s> occurs often in the <s1 slp1="fg">Ṛg</s1>-<s1 slp1="veda">veda</s1> and <s1 slp1="aTarva">Atharva</s1>-<s1 slp1="veda">veda</s1>, seldom in the <s1 slp1="brAhmaRa">Brāhmaṇa</s1>s, and its place is taken in <lang>classical Sanskṛt</lang> by <s>eva</s> and other particles.<info lex="inh"/>

; <L>30000.2<pc>171,3<k1>u<k2>u<e>1A
106907 old ¦ This particle may serve to give emphasis, like <s>id</s> and <s>eva</s>, especially after prepositions or demonstrative pronouns, in conjunction with <s>nu</s>, <s>vE</s>, <s>hi</s>, <s>cid</s>, &c. (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>aya/m u vAm puruta/mo</s> … <s>johavIti</s> [<ls>RV. iii, 62, 2</ls>], this very person [your worshipper] invokes you &c.) It is especially used in the figure of speech called Anaphora, and particularly when the pronouns are repeated (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>ta/m u stuza i/ndram ta/m gfRIze</s> [<ls>RV. ii, 20, 4</ls>], him I praise, <s1 slp1="indra">Indra</s1>, him I sing). It may be used in drawing a conclusion, like the English ‘now’ (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>ta/d u ta/TA na/ kuryAt</s> [<ls>ŚBr. v, 2, 2, 3</ls>], that now he should not do in such a manner), and is frequently found in interrogative sentences (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>ka/ u ta/c ciketa</s> [<ls>RV. i, 164, 48</ls>], who, I ask, should know that?)<info lex="inh"/>
;
106907 new ¦ This particle may serve to give emphasis, like <s>id</s> and <s>eva</s>, especially after prepositions or demonstrative pronouns, in conjunction with <s>nu</s>, <s>vE</s>, <s>hi</s>, <s>cid</s>, &c. (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>aya/m u vAm puruta/mo</s> … <s>johavIti</s> [<ls>RV. iii, 62, 2</ls>], this very person [your worshipper] invokes you &c.) It is especially used in the figure of speech called Anaphora, and particularly when the pronouns are repeated (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>ta/m u stuza i/ndram ta/m gfRIze</s> [<ls>RV. ii, 20, 4</ls>], him I praise, <s1 slp1="indra">Indra</s1>, him I sing). It may be used in drawing a conclusion, like the <lang>English</lang> ‘now’ (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>ta/d u ta/TA na/ kuryAt</s> [<ls>ŚBr. v, 2, 2, 3</ls>], that now he should not do in such a manner), and is frequently found in interrogative sentences (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>ka/ u ta/c ciketa</s> [<ls>RV. i, 164, 48</ls>], who, I ask, should know that?)<info lex="inh"/>

; <L>41336<pc>240,2<k1>ka<k2>ka/<h>2<e>1
145745 old <hom>2.</hom> <s>ka/</s> ¦ <s>kas</s>, <s>kA</s>, <s>kim</s>, <ab>interrog.</ab> <ab>pron.</ab> (See <s>kim</s> and <hom>2.</hom> <s>kad</s>, and <ab>cf.</ab> the following words in which the interrogative base <s>ka</s> appears, <s>katama</s>, <s>katara</s>, <s>kati</s>, <s>kaTam</s>, <s>kadA</s>, <s>karhi</s>, <s>kA</s>, &c.), who? which? what? In its declension <s>ka</s> follows the pronoun <s>tad</s> except in <ab>nom.</ab> <ab>acc.</ab> <ab>sing.</ab> <ab>neut.</ab>, where <s>kim</s> has taken the place of <s>kad</s> or <s>kat</s> in classical <ns>Sanskṛt</ns>; but the old form <s>kad</s> is found in the <s1 slp1="veda">Veda</s1> (See <ls>Gram. 227</ls>); <info lexcat="LEXID=pron,STEM=kim"/>
;
145745 new <hom>2.</hom> <s>ka/</s> ¦ <s>kas</s>, <s>kA</s>, <s>kim</s>, <ab>interrog.</ab> <ab>pron.</ab> (See <s>kim</s> and <hom>2.</hom> <s>kad</s>, and <ab>cf.</ab> the following words in which the interrogative base <s>ka</s> appears, <s>katama</s>, <s>katara</s>, <s>kati</s>, <s>kaTam</s>, <s>kadA</s>, <s>karhi</s>, <s>kA</s>, &c.), who? which? what? In its declension <s>ka</s> follows the pronoun <s>tad</s> except in <ab>nom.</ab> <ab>acc.</ab> <ab>sing.</ab> <ab>neut.</ab>, where <s>kim</s> has taken the place of <s>kad</s> or <s>kat</s> in <lang>classical Sanskṛt</lang>; but the old form <s>kad</s> is found in the <s1 slp1="veda">Veda</s1> (See <ls>Gram. 227</ls>); <info lexcat="LEXID=pron,STEM=kim"/>

; <L>41336.3<pc>240,3<k1>ka<k2>ka/<e>1A
145769 old <s>na kaScana</s>, no one), and a relative is sometimes connected with it (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>yat kiMcana</s>, anything whatsoever). Examples of <s>cid</s> with the interrogative are common; <s>vA</s> and <s>api</s> are not so common, but the latter is often found in classical <ns>Sanskṛt</ns> (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>kaScid</s>, any one;
;

; <L>50294<pc>282,3<k1>kim<k2>kim<h>b<e>2
174802 old <s>kim</s> <hom>b</hom> ¦ is much used as a particle of interrogation like the <ab>Lat.</ab> <etym>num</etym>, <etym>an</etym>, sometimes translatable by ‘whether?’ but oftener serving only like a note of interrogation to mark a question (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>kiM vyADA vane 'smin saMcaranti</s>, ‘do hunters roam about in this wood?’ In an interrogation the verb, if uncompounded with a preposition, generally retains its accent after <s>kim</s>, <ls>Pāṇ. viii, 1, 44</ls>). To this sense may be referred the <s>kim</s> expressing inferiority, deficiency, &c. at the beginning of compounds (<ab>e.g.</ab> <s>kiM-rAjan</s>, what sort of king? <ab>i.e.</ab> a bad king, <ls>Pāṇ. ii, 1, 64</ls>; <ls n="Pāṇ.">v, 4, 70</ls>)
;

; <L>61654.2<pc>338,2<k1>Kalu<k2>Ka/lu<e>1A
211213 old ¦ [<s>Kalu</s> is only exceptionally found at the beginning of a phrase; it is frequently combined with other particles, thus <s>a/Ta K°</s>, <s>u K°</s>, <s>vE/ K°</s>, <s>K° vE/</s>, = now then, now further, <ls>TS.</ls>; <ls>TBr.</ls>; <ls>ŚBr.</ls> &c.; in later <ns>Sanskṛt</ns> <s>Kalu</s> frequently does little more than lay stress on the word by which it is preceded, and is sometimes merely expletive; it is also a particle of prohibition (in which case it may be joined with the <ab>ind.p.</ab> [<s>Kalu kftvA</s>, ‘desist from doing that’], <ls>Nir. i, 5</ls> [also <s>°tam</s>]; <ls>Pāṇ. iii, 4, 18</ls>; <ls>Śiś. ii, 70</ls>); or of endearment, conciliation, and inquiry, <ls>L.</ls>; <s>na Kalu</s>, by no means, not at all, indeed not, <ls>R.</ls> &c.]<info lex="inh"/>

; <L>211231<pc>1045,3<k1>SakAra<k2>SakAra<e>2A

748499 old <hom>1.</hom> <s>za</s> ¦ the second of the three sibilants (it belongs to the cerebral class, and is sometimes substituted for <s>s</s>, and more rarely for <s>S</s>, and occasionally interchangeable with <s>K</s>; in sound it corresponds to <i>sh</i> in the English word <i>shun</i>; many roots which begin with <s>s</s> are written in the <s1 slp1="DAtu-pAWa">Dhātu-pāṭha</s1> with <s>z</s>, <ab>prob.</ab> to show that their initial <s>s</s> is liable to be cerebralized after certain prepositions).
